text.p: These are significant stories in the Nigerian press on Saturday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Prominent Yoruba politician and lawyer Toye Coker escapes assassination for the third time in three weeks.
- Former chief executive of Federal Environmental Protection Agency (FEPA) Olu Aina, in detention since October after fraud allegations, is released on police bail.
- Ethiopian Airlines plan to bury unclaimed bodies of five Nigerians who were passengers in the hijacked jet airliner that crashed in the sea, near the Comoros Islands in November.

- Erratic government policies, inadequate infrastructure and high interest rates on tools and machinery are the major factors impeding agricultural development in the country, the Practising Farmers Association of Nigeria (PFAN) says.
- Foreign portfolio investment in the country via the capital markets rises to $32.98 million in 1996 from $1.137 million in 1995, Hayford Alile, head of the Nigerian Stock Exchange (NSE), says.

- Self-exiled Ledum Mitee, acting president of the minority rights campaign group, Movement for the Survival of Ogoni Peoples (MOSOP), pleads for the release of 19 Ogoni youths. They have been detained by the military authorities since 1994 for the murder of four Ogoni chiefs.
- Hundreds of patients are stranded in the capital Abuja as public hospitals' doctors go on an indefinite strike to protest the detention of two colleagues by the Nigerian security authorities.
